item.title: Making Things Easier for somebody... by shortening CreateFrame
item.dc:creator: @Digital_Hotdogs Digital Hotdogs
item.description:
@Digital_Hotdogs wrote:

[quote=“x blitz x, post:3, topic:4672”][quote author=meanz link=topic=6086.msg61721#msg61721 date=1152611272]
Hey i got this idea… maybe its dumb… but…
the idea is to make it easier to know what frame is what?
like this

Class Frames
{
    public void Menu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(174); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void ClueMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(178); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void HelpMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(171); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
}

And then in a random place in Client.java

public void HelpMenu();
{
Frames.HelpMenu();
}

so u dont need to remember hmm… what was the HelpMenu frame again …
that will make it a lot easier but of course its not the best method,
since it may cause minor lagg on nooby comps…
[/quote]

Well, i wouldn’t be working on this if i was you, because you seem to know nothing. I can see this just by looking at your code.

Class Frames
{
    public void Menu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(174); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void ClueMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(178); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void HelpMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(171); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
}

There’s not supposed to be a ; after the method name, because that means there’s no body and needs to be declared abstract therefore the class also needs to be declared abstract. Also your method names don’t follow Java Coding Conventions.

There is also no variable called ‘outStream’ declared in your class.

public void HelpMenu();
{
Frames.HelpMenu();
}

Once again, doesn’t follow conventions and shouldn’t have a ; at the end of the method name.

Frames.HelpMenu();

Would not work because the methods are not static so you can’t access them staticly.[/quote]If you hadn’t noticed yet, this was posted 3 years ago.

Read full topic
item.source: Making Things Easier for somebody... by shortening CreateFrame

item.title: Making Things Easier for somebody... by shortening CreateFrame
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

[quote=“meanz, post:1, topic:4672”]Hey i got this idea… maybe its dumb… but…
the idea is to make it easier to know what frame is what?
like this

Class Frames
{
    public void Menu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(174); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void ClueMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(178); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void HelpMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(171); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
}

And then in a random place in Client.java

public void HelpMenu();
{
Frames.HelpMenu();
}

so u dont need to remember hmm… what was the HelpMenu frame again …
that will make it a lot easier but of course its not the best method,
since it may cause minor lagg on nooby comps…[/quote]

Well, i wouldn’t be working on this if i was you, because you seem to know nothing. I can see this just by looking at your code.

Class Frames
{
    public void Menu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(174); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void ClueMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(178); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
    public void HelpMenu();
    {
     outStream.createFrame(171); //This isnt right i just picked a random 1..
    }
}

There’s not supposed to be a ; after the method name, because that means there’s no body and needs to be declared abstract therefore the class also needs to be declared abstract. Also your method names don’t follow Java Coding Conventions.

There is also no variable called ‘outStream’ declared in your class.

public void HelpMenu();
{
Frames.HelpMenu();
}

Once again, doesn’t follow conventions and shouldn’t have a ; at the end of the method name.

Frames.HelpMenu();

Would not work because the methods are not static so you can’t access them staticly.

Frames.HelpMenu();

since it may cause minor lagg on nooby comps…
